name: rich cutshall
text:
Ok, I am going to try their pizza.  They have motivated me to try pizza again in the Philly area, which is a pizza desert, just by installing coal ovens. Philly made thin New York style is typically slapped together, tasteless and on some sort of mega-gluten rubber disk pretending to be a crust. Forget Chicago style, simplest pie in the world to make well but not here, no, it's NOT ok to use more of that same rubber compound in a dish and call it deep-dish or Chicago style. All that said, I am heading out to get one of these coal fired pies and the next paragraphs will tell the tale:  Dozens of possible missteps, but only one way to glory...  Give a damn about your product, craft each pie like it will raise the human spirit and singlehandedly bring about world peace.

So, here's the skinny, everything you are about to learn about Anthony's must be viewed through the prism of price. This is the single most expensive pizza I have ever eaten, period. John's coal fired pizza in the East Village costs less and delivers more, but that's to be expected from the best of the best. $29 bucks for a 12" two topping pie and a side salad with no dressing.

Bottom line, best crust outside NYC. Flaccid sauce, I ordered onions which were curious, honestly I think they were Sabrett hotdog onions cooked in sauce. The pepperoni was generous, but had very little flavor (if you want really good Pepperoni on the second best crust outside the five boros get a pie from Conti's in Princeton).  The cheese was excellent, well balanced with the pie and expertly baked.

There's no way to get to five stars with a pie this expensive unless it's perfect, two star Michelin perfect. The artsy-fartsy onions and Pizza Hut pepperoni won't make anyone happy, so three stars it is.

Expect excellent service; attentive, intelligent and insightful. Expect an excellent pie and a crisp fresh salad. Expect to pay an unusual amount for it all, and I guess be thankful you didn't have to drive to the big apple to get it?
